reviewText:
Lamia's Game Room is an Old maid card game remade into single-player game with story told in visual novel style. For those who don't know the rules - there is every card twice in the deck, except one, Lamia. Players take one card from opponent and match pairs of cards in hand until only the Lamia is in hand of any player - and that player loses.

In real life, this game revolves a lot around bluffing (fun and easy enough game to play it children) so even there is a sort of bluffing - as you can do specific emotions when opponents are picking a card from your hand. Every opponent will react differently to your emotions, some will get confused because of your grinning, some because of you'll be telling them to draw quickly.

The game, considering the low pricetag, has a nice artworks, especially for the cards. Sadly, if you are going to be playing the English version (which I assume), expect a terrible translation from original Japanese version. There are many typing errors and sentences that feel weird - it's sad that developers didn't pay a proper translator, I think it could justify increase of price to two euros.

With bad translation interest in the story goes off, and then there's just the repeating card game that's fun for one or two times, but not fun to play ten games in a row. Even though it's a cheap game and it has nice artworks, I don't think at all it could be worth recommending.


For more reviews, join Samurai Vader's Point of View group and follow my curator page, I'm always happy to see feedback about my reviews.

reviewText:
I admit I like the art in this, but I was expecting a deeper story. The developer should have run the script by a native english speaker to give it a quick looking over before publishing it, because it's a mess, with lots of grammatical errors and typos.

The mysterious game that this sinister entity is forcing you to play for your freedom? It's Old Maid with a bluffing system. I was expecting some sort of intricate double fanucci with the demonic host laughing and quipping when the players screwed up, building tension before each elimination. Nope. Old Maid with a bluffing system. So much disappointment.

On the bright side, it was a dollar, and it's got trading cards, if you're into those. Otherwise, give it a pass.

reviewText: Luckbased cardgames for freaks"Extremly basic cardgame in a horror VN enviroment. Unfortunately you have to win 4 times in each of the 11 levels but don't loose more than 2 times. You win if the bad joker doesn't remain in your card deck. So it's totally luck based. You choose cards from other players and they choose randomly from you. Your only chance is a bluff which can be used 3 times until it's depleted. In the end you have a 50:50 chance of a 50:50 chance for a bluff and a good/bad choice."

reviewText:
Lamia's Game Room

Lamia's Game Room is a casual card game done by Digital Crafter. Lamia's Game Room is a mystery card game that plays [for me] similar to Old Maid, with a visual novel type story tied to it. It's a bit short, it took me about 4-5 hours to beat and get all of the achievements. At the time I played, spelling and grammatical errors plauged the entire game.

The game is all about fooling your opponent by playing your cards and when you can, expressions right. You got a Lamia" card you need to get your opponent to take and hold onto

reviewText:
I should start off by saying that the art in this game looks nice (which seems to be the game's main selling point), since that's probably the only positive thing I can say about this game.

'Gothic style horror mystery card game' is a funny way to say 'glorified version of Old Maid plus badly written visual novel'.
The gameplay is overly simplified, and heavily depends on plain luck some times. Although the premise involves 'finding out your opponents' weakness', that really only works until halfway through the game. After that point, the patterns of each opponent are so vague you have a better chance just doing random guesses.

The translation is terrible, but at least it's still comprehensible most of the time. The story is nonexistent.  Whenever it feels like a character is getting some development or the game is hinting to something you jump right into the next chapter and that's never mentioned again.

Spoiler alert, if you manage to brave through 11 short but boring as hell matches, your big reward is a 'to be continued' screen as the game ends without even trying to explain anything about the plot it pretends to have. And that's just lovely.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So, this is basically a visual novel that is poorly translated (or written, maybe both), and uses the Old Maid game mechanic.

At times even if you feel you have a read on your opponent's tell you'll still pick the wrong card, and there will be times no matter what you do you'll end up losing. This can work in your favor sometimes: I was in the clear on the first turn, as 4 of my 5 cards were matches, and my opponent to my left was the first to pick cards, thus eliminating my hand. It still feels very RNG-ish, however, which can be a bad for something like this.

If the 'tells' were a little more visual or if they said something you could make an educated guess from that would be a big improvement. There were several times I had to win four games in a row and lost on my fourth game due to sheer luck. Very frustrating.

To be honest, while the story had its issues, it was the only reason I kept playing. It isn't a BAD game per say, just not very well put together.

HOWEVER, I am going to recommend this because of the price. The art is great, it has a creepy atmosphere, and you genuinely want to know more about the story. Plus, achievements simply for playing and beating the game (nothing missable). Worth it.

reviewText:
You get what you pay for and in many peoples cases it was nothing. Finally beat the game and got all the achievements and the game is crap plain and simple. Not a huge piece of crap but crap nonetheless. I love the games art and aesthetic their both good but that's just about all the game has going for it.

The game is basically old maid where you seek to avoid having the old maid card (lamia card) in your hand by the end of the game. You'd think it would be an ok game being based off of a classic but the game here is played out in the most stressful and overbearing way possible forcing you to win 4 GAMES IN A ROW just to pass to the next chapter.

-I would say it's an entirely luck based game, I WOULD, if only the game didn't cheat half of the time. At first i wasn't sure whether a luck based rng game would have been worse than a game that cheats. Stupid thought on my part because obviously a game that cheats like this in this sort of game is worse. I can't count how many times I've picked a card from the middle of my opponents hands only to be given another completely different card which is always the lamia card causing me to lose an otherwise winning game. And once you loose you have to play that match 4 MORE TIMES OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER SOMETIMES MORE if you lost once in the match.

-The story itself is crap too. You only get a few answers to what's happening and the ending is nonexistant. Not to mention that the dialogue is in bad english. Weird grammar and broken sentences everywhere. They need to get a new translator if they ever do a sequel.

-Also just found out that this is a cellphone game. I'm not sure which came first but if the app did I can understand why everything was subpar on pc.

Subpar game not ULTRA horrible but they really need to fix the english, and stop the ai from cheating. The story HAS potential and they should focus on making it better in a future sequel.

4/10 You get what you pay for and for this price it's fine.

reviewText:
I got this in a Visual Novel bundle and figured to get a good entertainment and easy 100%. Plus, it had trading cards to sell.

What I got is not what I was looking for. As written in the other reviews, it is not a VN, but a simple card game based on luck.

The story is awkward and cringeworthy, the English translation is terrible, and more often than not, the artwork is not pretty.

On a technical note, the game has a little reaction delay: where Ren'Py VNs react instantaneously on mouse clicks, this game takes a fraction of a second before it reacts. It's not much, but it's there and enough to annoy me.
On a 4:3 or 5:4 resolution, you cannot run the game in fullscreen without the graphics being stretched vertically - even although it is done in Unity, which allows extensive resolution configuration.
Apparently, this game only comes with 64 bit support. Seriously? There's NOTHING in the whole game that requires a 64 bit CPU. Even an old (32 bit) 500 MHz machine should be able to handle what is presented here. I can only speculate what might be the cause of this. Most likely, it's bad design.

For me, this seems like a quick cash grab.

Avoid. Even that cheap, you can do better.

reviewText:
This is my review of the game. This is my personal opinion and I try to be as objective as I can. I have not been paid to produce this review.

It is a nice little indie game. I quite enjoyed it and I will describe the positive and negative aspects of the game as I see them below:

+ Nice and enjoyable graphics
+ good price
+ interesting enough to return to the game
+ ok AI
+ wierd looking story

+/- Introduction to the game is a bit minimalistic (no idea in the beginning what is happening, unless it is by design - you being one of the players in the game - in that case it is a nice confusion)

- the game seems to be for one playthrough ie I did not find a way how to return to the beginning of the game thorugh game menu (reset progress)
- the text flow in the dialogues is painfully slow. You can skip the dialogues or you can fasten the flow up with mouse click, but still it is a bit unconvinient.

All in all It is a nice little game and for the money it is very ok to be played through once, camoon it is 99 cents :)

reviewText:
Product received for free

Overall, I enjoyed this game. It takes the classic card game Old Maid and makes it more interesting with the horror atmosphere and storyline. It's a decent way to spend a few hours. Gameplay is repetitive, basically the same card game but with different players each round. You should be able to decide very quickly if you like it or not.

Pros:
- Nice original artwork
- Interesting story. It could be a little less cryptic but I still liked it, especially the ending.
- Great soundtrack
- Price point is appropriate, makes it value for money. I received it for free but would gladly pay for it at this price range.

Cons:
- Game may feel a bit too luck-based. That's just the way Old Maid is, to be frank.
- English errors (I'm told these will be corrected in future updates).

reviewText:
tl;dr Old maid mixed with a gothic short story told in linear visual novel format.

The good
Artwork on characters and cards is very well done
Creepy, unsettling atmosphere and music
Game is easy to learn and play
Infinite continues, no excuse to give up
Story is suspenseful at the beginning, you want to know how it ends
The bad
Game is short, might take you about an hour depending on luck
Some typos and translation is a bit spotty, though you can still understand
Sequel hook for a game that doesn't really feel like it needs a sequel?
Story gets kind of muddled and confusing by the end, not a lot of resolution
As of the time of writing, the game is a dollar. It is well worth that price. Buy it.

reviewText:
I would have recommended this game if it wasn't for the huge amount of bad grammar. It is not big mistakes, but small stupid mistakes which could easily had been avoided, if the developer had checked one extra time or have someone fluent correct them.
Another (semi)failure is the bluffing-system which works as intended most of the time. I had a lot of trouble with it in the final chapter, and finally I won at my 12th attemped.
If you are into using your skills instead of luck in a game, this is NOT the game for you. And if you cannot ignore the problems with the grammar and the bluffing system you should stay away from the game too..

The GOOD things about the game is the art. This was the pure reason for my purchase. At some points ingame I was even a little spooked by the art, which is a HUGE PLUS in my opinion!
And then I personally like the game Old Maid"

reviewText:
I guess this game is fine... The premise is simple, you have to continously play (and win) Lamia's game or you'll die. The gameplay revolves around you constantly picking random cards from your opponent's hand, hoping that the RNG favors you, no strategy required (or available).

Pro:

Con:
-RNG
-1 billion obvious typos (Cancle, frist...)
-Translation is as good as a seahorse's foam soaked face. Like seriously, we're talking about cavemen level conversations. Me want smash you" "GUHGUHGUH"

For the low price of 1 buck

reviewText: God, I wish I really do, that I could give the game a more positive review, but I can't. The game truly failed to do what it set out to do so, make a simple but fun card game, however, instead, what we got is a long exercise in luck and random number generating. The game itself works so terribly, there's no way to control what the AI chooses, causing for it to be an unfun mess, the commands also, either work or don't work, and there is no pattern! No game should rely on luck alone, games are made to be an exercise in memory, motor skills and hand-to-eye co-ordination. Don't play this game if you're looking for something of that nature.
